Headline: Week in politics: Almost 100 days into Trump's second term, a look back
Summary: Nearly 100 days into his new term, President Trump has set an aggressive agenda, spending his political capital and losing some of the public approval he began with.

Headline: Why judges blocked the Trump admin's school DEI crackdown
Summary: On Thursday, three federal judges in Maryland, New Hampshire and Washington, D.C., said Trump's anti-DEI efforts were on shaky legal ground.

Headline: Justice Department revokes Biden-era protections for reporters in leak investigations
Summary: In a new memo, Attorney General Pam Bondi said the DOJ will allow for subpoenas, court orders and search warrants to get information and testimony from journalists.

Headline: Takeaways from the week — and how they've affected President Trump's polling numbers
Summary: This week, President Trump seemed to take a softer tone when asked about the trade war with China. Here are four takeaways from week 14 in our continued look at Trump's first 100 days in office.

Headline: NATO Secretary General speaks with NPR ahead of U.S. meetings
Summary: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte about U.S. involvement in major international conflicts under the Trump administration.

Headline: Federal agencies are reeling from Trump administration cuts to government
Summary:
Whether a "chainsaw," per Elon Musk, or "scalpel," as President Trump has said — the Trump administration is making deep cuts to the federal government within its first 100 days.

And Trump has appointed personal allies with little experience in government to key cabinet positions.

For the civil servants working to enact the missions of these government agencies, that's often meant another word: "chaos."

NPR correspondents Tom Bowman, Michele Kelemen and Selena Simmons-Duffin recap what they are hearing from federal workers at the Departments of Defense, State, and Health and Human Services.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

Headline: Finally! Shedeur Sanders gets picked by the Cleveland Browns in the NFL draft 5th round
Summary: He had to wait until the fifth round, but Shedeur Sanders, son of Pro Football Hall of Famer Deion Sanders — his coach at the University of Colorado — has finally been drafted by the NFL.

Headline: U.S. judge says 2-year-old apparently deported to Honduras 'with no meaningful process'
Summary: The toddler, a U.S. citizen, was apparently sent to Honduras with her mother and 11-year-old sister, even as a federal judge tried to contact an attorney representing the government.

Headline: Iran says 5 people are dead and more than 700 injured in a massive port explosion
Summary: A massive explosion and fire rocked a port in southern Iran possibly linked to a shipment of a chemical ingredient used to make missile propellant.

Headline: Built on a rich coffee history, Yemeni cafes find U.S. success and new challenges, too
Summary: Yemen is an ancient birthplace of the coffee trade, and immigrants fleeing its civil war have brought their culture here in the form of cafes. Hundreds of Yemeni coffee shops have opened in the U.S.

Headline: Opinion: Pope Francis's sympathy for migrants was personal
Summary: Pope Francis often spoke with great sympathy for immigrants and refugees. NPR's Scott Simon reminds us that the Pope's father fled Mussolini's Italy, immigrating to Argentina.

Headline: Trump meets Zelenskyy during visit to Pope Francis' funeral
Summary: It was their first face-to-face meeting since they argued in front of cameras in the Oval Office in February — and comes as efforts intensify to end Russia's war in Ukraine.

Headline: Photos: Pope Francis is laid to rest and mourned around the world
Summary: Pope Francis was honored with a funeral Mass Saturday morning in the Vatican City's St. Peter's Square. These are some of the images that captured the grief of those mourning him around the world.

Headline: These Australian twins have gone viral after speaking in synch
Summary: Meet Bridgette and Paula Powers, identical twins who speak in synch and dedicate themselves to animal conservation.

Headline: 10 years after Freddie Gray's death, his neighborhood looks for hope
Summary: There's still a lot of need in Baltimore's Sandtown-Winchester neighborhood, where Freddie Gray lived. People from the neighborhood work to meet it.

Headline: Employee cuts at Social Security are leaving remaining workers struggling to keep up
Summary: Social Security employees are feeling "overwhelmed" and wait times for phone services are up as workforce cuts from the Trump administration are being felt throughout the agency.

Headline: A look at the Kremlin's negotiating strategy
Summary: As the Trump administration continues to flood the news cycles with its efforts to end to the war in Ukraine, NPR looks at the Kremlin's negotiating strategy.

Headline: Crowds of mourners and dignitaries pay respects to Pope Francis at funeral service
Summary: It's a day of remembrance, mourning and celebration as thousands gather in Rome to pay their respects and say farewell to Pope Francis.

Headline: Virginia Giuffre, who accused Prince Andrew in Epstein sex trafficking scandal, has died
Summary: The American-born Giuffre, who lived in Australia for years, became an advocate for sex trafficking survivors after emerging as a central figure in financier Jeffrey Epstein's prolonged downfall.

Headline: Trump has his old friend Steve Witkoff leading his toughest diplomatic talks
Summary: President Trump has put Steve Witkoff — a friend from New York's real estate world — in charge of delicate talks on the war in Ukraine, Iran's nuclear ambitions and the conflict in Gaza.

Headline: A New Mission for Syria's Famed White Helmets
Summary: During Syria's long civil war, the White Helmets were known for running into harms way, rescuing civilians from the aftermath of regime attacks. Now with the regime gone, the famed organization is finding a new mission with new challenges. We go to Damascus to see them in action.

Headline: What it's like in the church Pope Francis chose as his final resting place
Summary: Pope Francis will be buried in St. Mary Major church, not Saint Peter's Basilica, in a break with tradition.
